text: Is it easier making money from tips, than making money from trading?

elements.text: Is it easier making money from tips, than making money from trading?

text:
I read an article about Star Lizard a few weeks ago. In the early days, lots of employees placed their own bets, but it caused issues. I think there's now an internal syndicate that they can all join if they want to bet on the company's strategy (I might be wrong, it might be a different syndicate!).

Anyway, a lot of modelers wouldn't have the risk appetite to bet their own accounts, otherwise they would be already.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text: I just wonder, if I started charging something like £10 a month for my picks, how would I even convince 10 people to start paying me? After that, if there were a few losers, I'd probably get a load of angry customers and possibly threats.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon

text: You'd need an effective social media campaign - and you might want to offer your different tips - like football tips, horses tips, tennis tips. You'll likely do ok on something every month. Finally you keep a running record of your 'winnings' which you do by assuming you matched the best plausible price for each selection.

text: Generating tips wouldn't be that hard. You can use traded volumes to infer prices that will be slightly different to exchange prices (I make no claim that this works). The the tips will just be anything higher than that inferred price. Tell the punters to ask for an extra 10% on the exchange when placing orders. And at the end of the day, if they are betting 1% of bank per selection, they are unlikely to lose much on the above.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text: <https://www.tradematesports.com/blog/brighton-football-owner-tony-bloom-people-rich-sports-betting> Interesting

attachments.title: How Brighton Football Club Owner Tony Bloom Got Rich On Sports Betting | 10 People Who Got Rich On Sports Betting
attachments.text: Arguably the UK’s most notorious sports bettor, Tony Bloom, is the owner of Starlizard, a company that describes itself as a betting consultancy. Based out of Camden, London, Starlizard is also the sole adviser for Bloom’s betting syndicate, who every weekend have £1 million riding on any given football game.
attachments.fallback: How Brighton Football Club Owner Tony Bloom Got Rich On Sports Betting | 10 People Who Got Rich On Sports Betting

elements.text: Interesting

text: I think that would be too complicated for most of the type of person who would purchase tips. Generally the gambling degens on twitter just want a selection and don't care about price and have no concept of value. They just want something that will win and when it doesn't they will sling you abuse. The more savvy punter would be asking "why is this bloke charging £10 a month for tips? If they were any good he'd be making shitloads backing them himself.". Once you don the cap of the salesman you have to prepare yourself for a flood of abuse unfortunately.

text: If the price is value you back it - if not you don't. I would assume that blindly backing selections at price X without consideration for value is going to lead to the poor house regardless of what X is.

text: And if you have a target value price - which any decent tip should supply then you would never use BFSP anyway because you don't know what it will be.

text: I'm not sure that you necessarily need a degree in maths. If you can self-teach, and be able to demonstrate that you know your stuff through programs you've written and your answers to interview questions, I think that would be sufficient. It might even be an advantage, as it would show initiative and a passion for the subject. However, you may find that, by the time you get to that stage, you know enough to profit from your knowledge independently (and don't need to work for someone else).

elements.text: I'm not sure that you necessarily need a degree in maths. If you can self-teach, and be able to demonstrate that you know your stuff through programs you've written and your answers to interview questions, I think that would be sufficient. However, you may find that, by the time you get to that stage, you know enough to profit from your knowledge independently (and don't need to work for someone else).
